body: Fixed a template syntax error, issue persists. https://psalm.dev/r/5063097d3b
Why would you need to redefine property at all? Psalm knows it's a `list<Foo>` already: https://psalm.dev/r/c13bb4fa11

Well I suppose that's fine. I had it for consistency with the rest of the class's properties having `@var` annotations, but if that's the official solution, is there or should there be something like `@psalm-var-inferred` to tell psalm to infer the type while leaving the `@var` annotation for non-psalm users? I haven't found the time to dig into psalm's code yet, so I don't know the complexity of fixing it, but as a user it seems like it'd be preferable for it to "just work".

From Psalm's type system perspective supporting this would actually be sound, and it already seems to be supported for other types: https://psalm.dev/r/8fa0853348. PHP does not allow it for native types (e.g. https://3v4l.org/9cWYX), but PHP doesn't have generics yet. This is similar to what we had before PHP supported covariant returns - people would put parent return type as native return type and specify descendant type via `@return` doblock tag.
Should probably also fix this false negative with templates: https://psalm.dev/r/40bd875b72

issue.title: Disable property invariance checks for properties with templates

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
Very much a work in progress, comments welcome.
Fix for #5371

I would like to have property invariance checks work correctly, but for now I'll at least settle for disabling them for properties containing a template.

So far I've changed `Union::hasTemplate` to check for arrays, lists, class-string-maps, and iterables containing templates, and the tests all pass. If this is the desired behavior of `hasTemplate` there's also `TGenericObject`, and possibly `TCallable` and others I haven't considered yet.

Any advice is much appreciated. I'm also trying to figure out how to update ClassAnalyzer.php:708 to check if `$guide_property_storage` has a template that's used by `$property_storage`, and then maybe clone `$guide_property_storage` and set the template to what `$property_storage` has before doing the `->equals` check, but I bet there's a better way to do that, cloning doesn't sound great for performance.
